com.sadakatsu.util

Class Permutations<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.sadakatsu.util.Permutations<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<java.util.List<T>>, java.util.Iterator<java.util.List<T>>

    public class Permutations<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<java.util.List<T>>, java.util.Iterator<java.util.List<T>>
    The Permutations class provides lazy iteration through all possible permutations of items in a Collection.
    Author:
    Joseph A. Craig

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Permutations(java.util.Collection<T> values)
      Instantiates a new Permutations instance for iterating over the permutations of the passed Collection.

      • get

        public static <T> Permutations<T> get(java.util.Collection<T> values)
        Calls the Permutations constructor with the passed arguments and returns the new instance. This method is provided for style. While the Permutations class is written so that an instance can be used for more than one iteration, it is unlikely that it would be. This means that one would end up with code like Permutations waste = new Permutations<>(items); for (Collection item : waste) // ... or for (Collection item : new Permutations<>(items)) // ... These two are functionally identical to calling this method, but I prefer how the resulting code looks: for (Collection item : Permutations.get(items)) // ...
        Parameters:
        values - The items from which to draw the permutations.
        Returns:
        The Permutations instance that will allow for iteration through the permutations of "values".
